questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis for a newborn who presents with protrusion of bowel loops through a defect in the abdominal wall located to the right side of the umbilicus?
questions.explanation:
Gastroschisis

Omphalocele

(Option A)

Definition

A congenital defect where the abdominal wall fails to close, leading to herniation of intestinal loops into the amniotic cavity.

M/c in premature/SGA babies

 

A congenital ventral body wall defect where portions of the midgut fail to return to the abdominal cavity after physiological herniation.

Location of defect

Right paraumbilical

Central

Sac

Absent, bowel is exposed.

Present (if not ruptured).

Sac is made of amnion, Wharton's jelly and peritoneum

Description

Free intestinal loops.

(Liver is not usually herniated)

Firm mass including liver, intestine and/ other organs (like stomach, spleen)

Umbilical cord

Adjacent to the defect

Attached to the sac

Associated anomalies

Associated anatomic defects are uncommon

Associated abnormalities are common and include:

  • Neural tube defect
  • Cardiac abnormalities
  • Chromosomal defect

Detection

  • Identified through fetal ultrasound.
  • Elevated alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) levels in maternal serum and amniotic fluid.

Elevated alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) concentrations in maternal serum and amniotic fluid, similar to gastroschisis.

Complication

  • Affected bowel loops may be damaged due to exposure to corrosive amniotic fluid.
  • Risk of volvulus, where the bowel twists around itself, compromising blood supply.
  • Feeding difficulties
  • Failure to thrive
  • Inguinal hernias
  • Gastroesophageal reflux
  • Occasionally esophagitis

Prognosis

Favorable

High mortality rates

questions.text: What is the cause of the greenish-black color of the initial stool in a newborn?
Phototherapy converts bilirubin to:

questions.explanation: Correct Answer B - 2

questions.text: What is a characteristic feature observed in physiological jaundice?

options.label: A
options.text: Increased indirect bilirubin, increased urobilinogen, absent bilirubin in urine

options.label: B
options.text: Increased direct bilirubin, increased urobilinogen, absent bilirubin in urine

options.label: C
options.text: Increased indirect bilirubin, absent urobilinogen, absent bilirubin in urine

options.label: D
options.text: Increased direct bilirubin, absent urobilinogen, absent bilirubin in urine

questions.correct_answer: A. Increased indirect bilirubin, increased urobilinogen, absent bilirubin in urine
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer A - Increased indirect bilirubin, increased urobilinogen, absent bilirubin in urine

Feature

Physiological Jaundice

Pathological Jaundice

Timing

Appears 24-72 hours after birth; peaks at 3-5 days; resolves by 1-2 weeks

Appears within 24 hours of birth or persists beyond the expected timeframe

Cause

Elevated unconjugated bilirubin due to increased production and immature liver function

Blood group incompatibility, infections, metabolic disorders, genetic conditions

Clinical Presentation

Yellowing of skin and sclera, starting from the face, progressing to the trunk and extremities

Similar to physiological jaundice, but potentially more severe and may include other symptoms

Treatment

Usually self-resolving; observation and reassurance; phototherapy may be used if needed (Option D)

Depends on the underlying cause; may include phototherapy, exchange transfusion, or specific treatments

Treatment

Usually self-resolving; observation and reassurance; phototherapy may be used if needed

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: Early discharge, skin-to-skin contact, exclusive breastfeeding

options.label: C
options.text: Skin-to-skin contact, exclusive breastfeeding, prevent infection

options.label: D
options.text: Early discharge, exclusive breastfeeding, prevent infection

questions.text: Which of the following can lead to neonatal seizures? 1. Hypocalcemia 2. Hyponatremia 3. Hypomagnesemia 4. Hypoglycemia
A 31-year-old lady with diabetes mellitus delivers a term neonate. Which of the following problems may be associated with the baby born to this lady?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer D - Hypoglycemia

Macrosomia/Large for Date Baby
  • Increased risk of birth trauma if forceps are used in obstructed labour.
  • Increased chances of perinatal asphyxia in prolonged labour.

Metabolic
  • Hypoglycemia (vs Option A)
  • Hypocalcemia (vs Option C)
  • Hypomagnesemia
  • Polycythemia
  • Neonatal jaundice

CVS
  • The most common congenital abnormality in infants of diabetic mothers (IDM) is congenital heart disease (CHD).
  • The most common congenital heart disease in IDM is ventricular septal defect (VSD). (vs Option B)
  • The most specific congenital heart disease in IDM is the transposition of the great arteries (TGA).

Respiratory System
  • Respiratory distress syndrome or hyaline membrane disease due to delayed maturation of surfactant.

CNS
  • The most common congenital neurologic abnormality in IDM: Neural tube defects.
  • Most specific neurologic abnormality in IDM: Sacral agenesis or caudal regression syndrome.

Renal
  • Renal vein thrombosis
  • Renal agenesis
  • Duplication of ureter
  • Hydroureteronephrosis

GI
  • Duodenal atresia
  • Lazy/small left colon syndrome

Long Term Problems
  • Blindness
  • Obesity
  • Nonketotic hypoglycemia
  • Deafness

questions.text: Identify the condition in a neonate with the swelling of the head shown in the image below at a few weeks of life?
questions.explanation:
Feature

Caput succedaneum (Option A)

Cephalhematoma

(Option B)

Subgaleal hemorrhage (Option C)

Location

At point of contact; can extend across sutures

Usually over parietal bones; does not cross sutures

Beneath epicranial aponeurosis; may extend to orbits, nape of neck

Characteristic findings

Vaguely demarcated; pitting edema that shifts with gravity

Distinct margins; initially firm, more fluctuant after 48 h

Firm to fluctuant; ill-defined borders; may have crepitus or fluid waves

Timing

Maximal size and firmness at birth; resolves in 48-72 h

Increases after birth for 12-24 h; resolution over 2-3 wk

Progressive after birth; resolution over 2-3 wk

Volume of blood

Minimal

Rarely severe

May be massive, especially if there is an associated coagulopathy

Association

-

Linear skull fracture (5-25%); hyperbilirubinemia

-

questions.text: A 3.5 kg term neonate born to a mother with eclampsia did not cry at birth. Which of the following is the criterion for perinatal asphyxia?
One-day-old term neonate presented with respiratory distress, tachypnea, SpO2-80%, and scaphoid abdomen. Which of the following cannot be used in resuscitation?
questions.explanation:
Etiology

Failure of closure of the pleuroperitoneal canal during fetal development (normally by 8-10 weeks gestation).

Prevalence of Sides

Left-sided hernias are more common (80%).

Common Hernia Sites

1. Foramen of Morgagni: Hernia in the anteromedial part of the diaphragm (defect between sternal and costal attachments), often involving the transverse colon.

2. Foramen of Bochdalek: Hernia through the dome of the diaphragm posterolaterally.

 

Pathophysiology

Pulmonary hypoplasia (bilateral), leading to smaller bronchi, reduced bronchial branching, and less alveolar surface area. May cause pulmonary hypertension due to thickened arteriolar smooth muscle.

Clinical Features
  • Respiratory distress at birth
  • Grunting respiration
  • Chest retractions
  • Dyspnea
  • Cyanosis
  • Scaphoid abdomen
  • Decreased breath sounds with bowel sounds heard over the chest
  • Shifting of heart sounds to the right (for left-sided CDH).

Associated Complications

Pulmonary hypoplasia, pulmonary hypertension, increased systemic vasoactive factors.

Diagnosis

Clinical evaluation (respiratory distress, scaphoid abdomen, etc.), imaging (X-ray, ultrasound, or CT scan).

Management

Immediate resuscitation and stabilization, surgical repair of the diaphragm defect.

Contraindication

Bag and mask ventilation is contraindicated due to risk of insufflation of abdominal contents into the chest cavity. Intubation is preferred.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an indicator of fetal lung maturity?

options.label: D
options.text: Nile blue test showing >50% of blue cells

questions.correct_answer: D. Nile blue test showing >50% of blue cells
questions.explanation:
Test

Description

Interpretation

Lecithin-sphingomyelin (L/S) ratio
  • Measures the ratio of lecithin to sphingomyelin in amniotic fluid.
  • Lecithin increases with lung maturity, while sphingomyelin remains stable.

A ratio >2 indicates fetal lung maturity. (Option A ruled out)

Shake Test (Bubble Test, Clement's Test)
  • Amniotic fluid is mixed with 95% ethanol and shaken.
  • Observed for bubbles at the meniscus after 15 minutes.

A complete ring of bubbles suggests fetal lung maturity. (Option B ruled out)

Phosphatidylglycerol (PG)
  • Marker of lung maturity, typically appears in amniotic fluid after 35 weeks of gestation.

Presence of PG indicates fetal lung maturity. (Option C ruled out)

Nile Blue Test
  • Uses 0.1% Nile blue sulfate to stain desquamated fetal cells in amniotic fluid.
  • Observes for color changes in stained cells.
  • >50% orange-stained cells indicate lung maturity.
  • Blue-stained cells do not indicate maturity.

questions.text: In a baby born with meconium-stained liquor, which of the following are recommended as per Neonatal Resuscitation guidelines? 1. Intrapartum suction of nose and mouth before delivery of shoulder 2. Intratracheal suction in case of non-vigorous baby 3. Gentle suction of nose and mouth in case of vigorous baby 4. PPV in case of non-vigorous baby after early steps
What is the amount of milk given to a term baby in the first 24 hours after delivery?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer C - 60ml/kg

questions.text: According to the neonatal resuscitation protocol, below what heart rate are chest compressions initiated?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer B - 60

NRP Neonatal Chest Compressions Guidelines

Indications
  • Heart rate below 60/min despite 30 seconds of PPV
  • Continue until heart rate is 60/min or more

Technique
  • Two-thumb technique is preferred
  • Thumbs depress lower third of sternum
  • Hands encircle torso with fingers supporting back
  • Avoid using xiphisternum
  • Thumbs remain in contact during compression and release

Depth & Rate
  • Compress chest three times
  • One breath for ventilation
  • Use 3:1 ratio (compression:ventilation)
  • Complete cycle in 2 minutes
  • Check femoral or carotid pulse periodically

Evaluation
  • Check heart rate after 60 seconds of CC
  • HR below 60: Continue CC with PPV and medications
  • HR 60 or above: Stop CC, continue PPV until HR >100 and spontaneous breathing

Important Considerations
  • Must always accompany with BMV (bag-mask ventilation)
  • Only oxygenated blood should be circulated
  • Ventilate between compressions
  • Positive breath should follow every third CC

Complications
  • Broken ribs
  • Liver laceration
  • Pneumothorax

questions.text: A newborn baby presents with irritability and cyanosis which subsides on crying. On examination, you are unable to pass a nasogastric tube and no mist formation is noted on the laryngeal mirror test. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

Correct option D

Pulse rate Absent <100/min >100/min

questions.text: What is the usual cause of jaundice that occurs either at birth or within 24 hours of birth ?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A - Erythroblastosis

Unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia

Increased production of bilirubin

Decreased conjugation of bilirubin

  • Hemolytic disease of newborn or erythroblastosis fetalis
  • Hereditary spherocytosis
  • G6PD deficiency
  • Polycythemia
  • Delayed cord clamping
  • Cephalohematoma
  • Crigler-Najjar syndrome
  • Deficiency of UDP-glucuronyl transferase enzyme:
    • Type I: Complete deficiency
    • Type II: partial deficiency
  • Down syndrome
  • Congenital hypothyroidism

Conjugated hyperbilirubinemia

Non-obstructive causes

Obstructive causes

  • Infections:
    • Viral: EBV, CMV, Hepatitis
    • Bacterial: Congenital TB (Ghon focus seen in liver)
    • Parasitic: Toxoplasmosis
  • Metabolic:
    • Hereditary fructose intolerance
    • α-1 antitrypsin deficiency
    • Cystic Fibrosis
    • Tyrosinemia
    • Galactosemia
  • Toxins:
    • Neonatal Sepsis
    • UTI
  • Idiopathic neonatal hepatitis
  • Intrahepatic causes:
    • Congenital hepatic fibrosis
    • Caroli's disease
    • Progressive familial intrahepatic cholestasis
    • Alagille syndrome
    • Dubin-Johnson syndrome
    • Rotor Syndrome
  • Extrahepatic causes:
    • Extra hepatic biliary atresia
    • Choledochal cyst
    • Stone
    • Stricture
    • Mass

questions.text: Which of the following indicates a "infant at risk"?

options.label: B
options.text: Mother who has not taken folic acid during pregnancy

options.label: C
options.text: Infant with history of premature birth <32 weeks

questions.correct_answer: C. Infant with history of premature birth <32 weeks
questions.explanation:
Correct option C: Infant with history of premature birth <32 week

Maternal factors Current pregnancy factors Labor or delivery process factor Newborn related factors
  • Mother age <16 years or >40 years
  • Unmarried or single mother
  • Poverty
  • Smoking / Alcohol
  • Medical conditions:
    • DM
    • Thyroid disease
    • Renal disease
    • UTI
    • Anemia
  • Obstetrics history: Past H/O -
    • Preterm delivery
    • IUGR
    • IUD
    • Premature rupture of membranes
  • Multiple gestation
  • Presence of polyhydramnios / oligohydramnios
  • Preeclampsia
  • IUGR
  • Shorter interpregnancy time
  • Preterm/post-term delivery
  • Fetal distress during delivery
  • Meconium stained liquor
  • Placental anomalies
  • Low 5-minute APGAR score
  • SFD/LFD
  • Shock
  • Congenital anomalies

questions.text: The procedure displayed below is:
questions.explanation:
Correct option C: Nasogastric tu

Diagnostic indications Therapeutic indications
  • Saline load test for gastric outlet obstruction
  • To assess free and total acid in peptic ulcer patient
  • To diagnose tracheoesophageal fistula
  • For decompression
    • Intestinal or gastric outlet obstruction
    • Perforation peritonitis
    • Upper GI bleed
    • Upper abdominal surgery
  • Nutrition - Enteral nutrition
